block.p: Gulliver Preparatory School in Miami, disqualified from a cross-country event because of the team's high-cut briefs, yesterday lost its appeal to get its third-place finish restored.

The executive board of the Florida High School Activities Association upheld the race officials' decision that Gulliver's form-fitting briefs, now standard in elite running, were too short at the state's cross-country championship on Nov. 18 in Jacksonville.
Gulliver Preparatory School in Miami, disqualified from a cross-country event because of the team's high-cut briefs, yesterday lost its appeal to get its third-place finish restored.

The executive board of the Florida High School Activities Association upheld the race officials' decision that Gulliver's form-fitting briefs, now standard in elite running, were too short at the state's cross-country championship on Nov. 18 in Jacksonville.
I'm disappointed," said Karen Callaway, who coaches the team. "I was hoping the executive board would be fair-minded."

The National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations permits the tight briefs for girls, but stipulates that "abbreviated" (French or high-cut) shorts and similar apparel are not permitted unless worn underneath a standard running short.

Individual states are permitted to interpret the clause. The briefs are worn by New York's top girls' cross-country teams, in Saratoga Springs and Shenendehowa, which were co-ranked No. 1 in the country last fall. However, the Red Bank Catholic girls wore traditional shorts while winning in New Jersey, where the briefs are prohibited.
Callaway wasn't sure what Gulliver would be wearing for Florida's coming track season. "I don't know what we want to do," she said, adding half-jokingly, "long hoop skirts, maybe."
